text: I will set down a tale as it was told to me by one who had it of his
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: father, which latter had it of HIS father, this last having in like
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: manner had it of HIS father--and so on, back and still back, three
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: hundred years and more, the fathers transmitting it to the sons and so
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: preserving it. <U+00A0>It may be history, it may be only a legend, a tradition.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: It may have happened, it may not have happened: <U+00A0>but it COULD have
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: happened. <U+00A0>It may be that the wise and the learned believed it in the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: old days; it may be that only the unlearned and the simple loved it and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: JUSTICE AND RETRIBUTION
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: NOTES
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: CHAPTER I. The birth of the Prince and the Pauper.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: In the ancient city of London, on a certain autumn day in the second
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: quarter of the sixteenth century, a boy was born to a poor family of the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: name of Canty, who did not want him. <U+00A0>On the same day another English
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: child was born to a rich family of the name of Tudor, who did want him.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: All England wanted him too. <U+00A0>England had so longed for him, and hoped
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: for him, and prayed God for him, that, now that he was really come, the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: people went nearly mad for joy. <U+00A0>Mere acquaintances hugged and kissed
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: each other and cried. Everybody took a holiday, and high and low, rich
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and poor, feasted and danced and sang, and got very mellow; and they
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: kept this up for days and nights together. <U+00A0>By day, London was a sight
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: to see, with gay banners waving from every balcony and housetop, and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: splendid pageants marching along. <U+00A0>By night, it was again a sight
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: to see, with its great bonfires at every corner, and its troops of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: revellers making merry around them. <U+00A0>There was no talk in all England
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: but of the new baby, Edward Tudor, Prince of Wales, who lay lapped in
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: silks and satins, unconscious of all this fuss, and not knowing that
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: great lords and ladies were tending him and watching over him--and not
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: caring, either. <U+00A0>But there was no talk about the other baby, Tom Canty,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: lapped in his poor rags, except among the family of paupers whom he had
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: just come to trouble with his presence.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: CHAPTER II. Tom's early life.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Let us skip a number of years.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: London was fifteen hundred years old, and was a great town--for that
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: day. It had a hundred thousand inhabitants--some think double as many.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: <U+00A0>The streets were very narrow, and crooked, and dirty, especially in the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: part where Tom Canty lived, which was not far from London Bridge. <U+00A0>The
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: houses were of wood, with the second story projecting over the first,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the third sticking its elbows out beyond the second. <U+00A0>The higher
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: the houses grew, the broader they grew. <U+00A0>They were skeletons of strong
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: criss-cross beams, with solid material between, coated with plaster.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: <U+00A0>The beams were painted red or blue or black, according to the owner's
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: taste, and this gave the houses a very picturesque look. <U+00A0>The windows
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: were small, glazed with little diamond-shaped panes, and they opened
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: outward, on hinges, like doors.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: The house which Tom's father lived in was up a foul little pocket called
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Offal Court, out of Pudding Lane. <U+00A0>It was small, decayed, and rickety,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: but it was packed full of wretchedly poor families. Canty's tribe
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: occupied a room on the third floor. <U+00A0>The mother and father had a sort of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: bedstead in the corner; but Tom, his grandmother, and his two sisters,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Bet and Nan, were not restricted--they had all the floor to themselves,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and might sleep where they chose. <U+00A0>There were the remains of a blanket
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: or two, and some bundles of ancient and dirty straw, but these could not
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: rightly be called beds, for they were not organised; they were kicked
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: into a general pile, mornings, and selections made from the mass at
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: night, for service.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Bet and Nan were fifteen years old--twins. <U+00A0>They were good-hearted
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: girls, unclean, clothed in rags, and profoundly ignorant. <U+00A0>Their mother
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: was like them. <U+00A0>But the father and the grandmother were a couple of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: fiends. <U+00A0>They got drunk whenever they could; then they fought each other
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: or anybody else who came in the way; they cursed and swore always, drunk
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: or sober; John Canty was a thief, and his mother a beggar. <U+00A0>They made
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: beggars of the children, but failed to make thieves of them. <U+00A0>Among,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: but not of, the dreadful rabble that inhabited the house, was a good old
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: priest whom the King had turned out of house and home with a pension of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: a few farthings, and he used to get the children aside and teach them
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: right ways secretly. Father Andrew also taught Tom a little Latin, and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: how to read and write; and would have done the same with the girls,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: but they were afraid of the jeers of their friends, who could not have
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: endured such a queer accomplishment in them.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: All Offal Court was just such another hive as Canty's house.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Drunkenness, riot and brawling were the order, there, every night and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: nearly all night long. <U+00A0>Broken heads were as common as hunger in that
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: place. <U+00A0>Yet little Tom was not unhappy. <U+00A0>He had a hard time of it, but
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: did not know it. <U+00A0>It was the sort of time that all the Offal Court boys
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: had, therefore he supposed it was the correct and comfortable thing.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: <U+00A0>When he came home empty-handed at night, he knew his father would
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: curse him and thrash him first, and that when he was done the awful
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: grandmother would do it all over again and improve on it; and that away
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the night his starving mother would slip to him stealthily with any
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: miserable scrap or crust she had been able to save for him by going
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: hungry herself, notwithstanding she was often caught in that sort of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: treason and soundly beaten for it by her husband.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: No, Tom's life went along well enough, especially in summer. <U+00A0>He only
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: begged just enough to save himself, for the laws against mendicancy were
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: stringent, and the penalties heavy; so he put in a good deal of his time
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: listening to good Father Andrew's charming old tales and legends
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: about giants and fairies, dwarfs and genii, and enchanted castles, and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: gorgeous kings and princes. <U+00A0>His head grew to be full of these wonderful
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: things, and many a night as he lay in the dark on his scant and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: offensive straw, tired, hungry, and smarting from a thrashing, he
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: unleashed his imagination and soon forgot his aches and pains in
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: delicious picturings to himself of the charmed life of a petted prince
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: in a regal palace. <U+00A0>One desire came in time to haunt him day and night:
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: <U+00A0>it was to see a real prince, with his own eyes. <U+00A0>He spoke of it once to
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: some of his Offal Court comrades; but they jeered him and scoffed him so
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: unmercifully that he was glad to keep his dream to himself after that.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: He often read the priest's old books and got him to explain and enlarge
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon them. <U+00A0>His dreamings and readings worked certain changes in him,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: by-and-by. <U+00A0>His dream-people were so fine that he grew to lament his
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: shabby clothing and his dirt, and to wish to be clean and better clad.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: <U+00A0>He went on playing in the mud just the same, and enjoying it, too; but,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: instead of splashing around in the Thames solely for the fun of it,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: he began to find an added value in it because of the washings and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: cleansings it afforded.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Tom could always find something going on around the Maypole in
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cheapside, and at the fairs; and now and then he and the rest of London
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: had a chance to see a military parade when some famous unfortunate was
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: carried prisoner to the Tower, by land or boat. One summer's day he saw
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: poor Anne Askew and three men burned at the stake in Smithfield, and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: heard an ex-Bishop preach a sermon to them which did not interest him.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, Tom's life was varied and pleasant enough, on the whole.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: By-and-by Tom's reading and dreaming about princely life wrought such a
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong effect upon him that he began to _act_ the prince, unconsciously.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: His speech and manners became curiously ceremonious and courtly, to the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: vast admiration and amusement of his intimates. <U+00A0>But Tom's influence
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: among these young people began to grow now, day by day; and in time he
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: came to be looked up to, by them, with a sort of wondering awe, as a
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: superior being. <U+00A0>He seemed to know so much! and he could do and say such
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: marvellous things! and withal, he was so deep and wise! <U+00A0>Tom's remarks,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and Tom's performances, were reported by the boys to their elders; and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: these, also, presently began to discuss Tom Canty, and to regard him
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: as a most gifted and extraordinary creature. <U+00A0>Full-grown people brought
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: their perplexities to Tom for solution, and were often astonished at the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: wit and wisdom of his decisions. <U+00A0>In fact he was become a hero to all
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: who knew him except his own family--these, only, saw nothing in him.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Privately, after a while, Tom organised a royal court! <U+00A0>He was the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: prince; his special comrades were guards, chamberlains, equerries, lords
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and ladies in waiting, and the royal family. <U+00A0>Daily the mock prince was
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: received with elaborate ceremonials borrowed by Tom from his romantic
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: readings; daily the great affairs of the mimic kingdom were discussed
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the royal council, and daily his mimic highness issued decrees to his
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: imaginary armies, navies, and viceroyalties.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: After which, he would go forth in his rags and beg a few farthings, eat
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: his poor crust, take his customary cuffs and abuse, and then stretch
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: himself upon his handful of foul straw, and resume his empty grandeurs
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: in his dreams.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: And still his desire to look just once upon a real prince, in the flesh,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: grew upon him, day by day, and week by week, until at last it absorbed
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: all other desires, and became the one passion of his life.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: One January day, on his usual begging tour, he tramped despondently up
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and down the region round about Mincing Lane and Little East Cheap, hour
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: after hour, bare-footed and cold, looking in at cook-shop windows and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: longing for the dreadful pork-pies and other deadly inventions displayed
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: there--for to him these were dainties fit for the angels; that is,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: judging by the smell, they were--for it had never been his good luck to
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: own and eat one. There was a cold drizzle of rain; the atmosphere was
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: murky; it was a melancholy day. <U+00A0>At night Tom reached home so wet and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: tired and hungry that it was not possible for his father and grandmother
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: to observe his forlorn condition and not be moved--after their fashion;
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: wherefore they gave him a brisk cuffing at once and sent him to bed.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: <U+00A0>For a long time his pain and hunger, and the swearing and fighting
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: going on in the building, kept him awake; but at last his thoughts
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: drifted away to far, romantic lands, and he fell asleep in the company
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: of jewelled and gilded princelings who live in vast palaces, and had
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: servants salaaming before them or flying to execute their orders. <U+00A0>And
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: then, as usual, he dreamed that _he_ was a princeling himself.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: All night long the glories of his royal estate shone upon him; he moved
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: among great lords and ladies, in a blaze of light, breathing perfumes,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: drinking in delicious music, and answering the reverent obeisances of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: the glittering throng as it parted to make way for him, with here a
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: smile, and there a nod of his princely head.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: And when he awoke in the morning and looked upon the wretchedness
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: about him, his dream had had its usual effect--it had intensified the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: sordidness of his surroundings a thousandfold. <U+00A0>Then came bitterness,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and heart-break, and tears.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: CHAPTER III. Tom's meeting with the Prince.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Tom got up hungry, and sauntered hungry away, but with his thoughts busy
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: with the shadowy splendours of his night's dreams. He wandered here
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and there in the city, hardly noticing where he was going, or what
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: was happening around him. <U+00A0>People jostled him, and some gave him rough
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: speech; but it was all lost on the musing boy. <U+00A0>By-and-by he found
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: himself at Temple Bar, the farthest from home he had ever travelled in
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: that direction. <U+00A0>He stopped and considered a moment, then fell into his
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: imaginings again, and passed on outside the walls of London. <U+00A0>The Strand
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: had ceased to be a country-road then, and regarded itself as a street,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: but by a strained construction; for, though there was a tolerably
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: compact row of houses on one side of it, there were only some scattered
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: great buildings on the other, these being palaces of rich nobles, with
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: ample and beautiful grounds stretching to the river--grounds that are
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: now closely packed with grim acres of brick and stone.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Tom discovered Charing Village presently, and rested himself at the
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: beautiful cross built there by a bereaved king of earlier days; then
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: idled down a quiet, lovely road, past the great cardinal's
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: stately palace, toward a far more mighty and majestic palace
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: beyond--Westminster. Tom stared in glad wonder at the vast pile of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: masonry, the wide-spreading wings, the frowning bastions and turrets,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: the huge stone gateway, with its gilded bars and its magnificent array
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: of colossal granite lions, and other the signs and symbols of English
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: royalty. <U+00A0>Was the desire of his soul to be satisfied at last? <U+00A0>Here,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: indeed, was a king's palace. <U+00A0>Might he not hope to see a prince now--a
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: prince of flesh and blood, if Heaven were willing?
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: At each side of the gilded gate stood a living statue--that is to say,
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: an erect and stately and motionless man-at-arms, clad from head to heel
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: in shining steel armour. <U+00A0>At a respectful distance were many country
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: folk, and people from the city, waiting for any chance glimpse of
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: royalty that might offer. <U+00A0>Splendid carriages, with splendid people
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: in them and splendid servants outside, were arriving and departing by
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: several other noble gateways that pierced the royal enclosure.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: Poor little Tom, in his rags, approached, and was moving slowly and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: timidly past the sentinels, with a beating heart and a rising hope, when
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: all at once he caught sight through the golden bars of a spectacle that
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: almost made him shout for joy. <U+00A0>Within was a comely boy, tanned and
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises, whose clothing was all
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: of lovely silks and satins, shining with jewels; at his hip a little
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: jewelled sword and dagger; dainty buskins on his feet, with red heels;
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: and on his head a jaunty crimson cap, with drooping plumes fastened
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: with a great sparkling gem. <U+00A0>Several gorgeous gentlemen stood near--his
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: servants, without a doubt. <U+00A0>Oh! he was a prince--a prince, a living
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: prince, a real prince--without the shadow of a question; and the prayer
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the pauper-boy's heart was answered at last.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: GENERAL NOTE.
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: One hears much about the 'hideous Blue Laws of Connecticut,' and is
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: accustomed to shudder piously when they are mentioned. <U+00A0>There are people
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: in America--and even in England!--who imagine that they were a very
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: monument of malignity, pitilessness, and inhumanity; whereas in reality
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: they were about the first _sweeping departure from judicial atrocity_
title: The Prince and the Pauper
author: Twain, Mark

text: which the 'civilised' world had seen. <U+00A0>This humane and kindly Blue Law
title: The Prince and the Pauper

title: The Prince and the Pauper
